result_equations.equation: oint_S vec(g) cdot d vec(A) = -4 pi G M_{enc}
grad cdot vec(g) = -4 pi G rho

explanation: Gauss's law for gravity relates the gravitational field flux through a closed surface to the enclosed mass. Unlike electrostatics, gravitational forces are always attractive, resulting in negative flux and the negative sign in the law. This formulation provides the field-theoretic foundation for gravity, connecting Newton's law to modern field theory concepts.

definitions.definition: Differential area element vector pointing outward from surface
Total mass enclosed by surface S

assumptions.text: Newtonian gravity applies (weak field, low velocity limit)
Mass distribution is continuous and well-defined
Gravitational field is differentiable and well-behaved
No relativistic effects (general relativity corrections ignored)
Newton's law of universal gravitation applies
Superposition principle holds for gravitational fields
Mass distribution is localized and well-defined

derivation.description: Start with Newton's law of universal gravitation for the force between two masses.
Define gravitational field as force per unit test mass, with negative sign indicating attractive nature.
Calculate flux of gravitational field through spherical surface of radius r.
derivation.equation: oint_S vec(g) cdot d vec(A) = vec(g) cdot 4 pi r^2

derivation.description: Substitute field expression to show flux equals -4πGM, independent of radius.
derivation.equation: oint_S vec(g) cdot d vec(A) = -G M/r^2 cdot 4 pi r^2 = -4 pi G M

derivation.description: Apply divergence theorem to convert surface integral to volume integral.
derivation.equation: int_V grad cdot vec(g) dV = oint_S vec(g) cdot d vec(A)

derivation.description: Express enclosed mass as integral of density over volume.
derivation.equation: int_V grad cdot vec(g) dV = -4 pi G int_V rho dV

derivation.description: Equate integrands to obtain differential form of Gauss's law for gravity.
derivation.equation: grad cdot vec(g) = -4 pi G rho
